#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Fiordland National Park
#Text=Fiordland National Park
#Text=, covering over 1.2 million hectares , is New Zealand ' s largest national park and one of the largest in the world .
#Text=The park , together with the adjoining Mount Aspiring National Park , occupies the south west corner of the South Island and is listed as a UNESCO World Heritage site .
#Text=The park was one of the film sets for the Lord of the Rings film trilogy .
#Text=Understand
#Text=Fiordland , as the name suggests , is home to several fiords — steep-sided inlets carved by glaciers during the last ice age , then later drowned by the rising sea .
#Text=Its rugged landscape remains one of the least explored areas of New Zealand .
#Text=Although the park has about 500 km of formed walking tracks , these are mostly confined to eastern and northern parts of the park .
#Text=Like all of New Zealand 's national parks , it is managed by the Department of Conservation ( DOC ) .
#Text=The department aims to allow the public to enjoy the park , while also preserving the environment .
#Text=There are relatively few restrictions on access by individual visitors , though commercial activity is carefully ( some might say strictly ) controlled .
#Text=The main visitor information centre is in the township of Te Anau .
#Text=There are park ranger outposts at major visitor locations .
#Text=Visitors intending to stay in the park overnight are advised to inform the park rangers of their intentions .
#Text=In the event of an emergency , these intentions will be used as part of any search and rescue operation .
#Text=Flora and fauna
#Text=The area is so remote and unexplored that some speculate that species thought extinct in New Zealand may still live in the park .
#Text=The takahe , a flightless bird previously thought extinct , was discovered in a remote part of the park in 1948 .
#Text=The kakapo , the world 's only flightless parrot , survived in Fiordland longer than any other place on New Zealand 's two main islands , although even here it died out by the 1980s .
#Text=A recovery project has been started on offshore islands free of the predators that threatened its survival on the mainland .
#Text=Sandflies
#Text=are an obvious ( and annoying ) demonstration of the insect life that inhabits the area .
#Text=Climate
#Text=The weather in the park can change dramatically over the space of a few hours and over a few kilometres .
#Text=Visitors should always be prepared for rain , which can be heavy and prolonged .
#Text=The park has over 200 rain days per year , though different parts of the park receive widely different rainfalls .

#Text=Te Anau , with 1200 mm ( 40 inches ) annual rainfall is almost as dry as much of the eastern South Island , while Milford Sound , with 8000 mm ( 320 inches ) annual rainfall , is truly rainforest and waterfall territory .
#Text=Aircraft
#Text=Aircraft are part of the Fiordland National Park scene .
#Text=DOC uses them to carry out its duties in the park , including pest control .
#Text=Aircraft service the walking track and remove every bit of waste , including toilet waste .
#Text=As there are no roads , all lodge , track maintenance and building is enabled by aircraft and all supplies to the lodges are flown in .
#Text=If you injure yourself so you ca n't continue or you go missing , aircraft are the only practical method to carry out search and rescue .
#Text=For many people the only way they can access the park is by aircraft either because of lack of time , age or infirmity .
#Text=The other important consideration is that aircraft make the least real environmental impact of any of the users of the park .
#Text=Get in
#Text=State Highway 94
#Text=.
#Text=Drive or bus in to Te Anau , the park 's " gateway " , from Queenstown or Invercargill .
#Text=You can also fly into Milford or Doubtful Sounds from Queenstown , Glenorchy or Te Anau .
#Text=Manapouri ( 15 min drive from Te Anau ) is another place to start exploring Fiordland .
#Text=Daily departures to Doubtful Sound ( also within Fiordland National Park ) .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Fly , bus , walk or boat
#Text=Destinations
#Text=Milford Sound
#Text=Te Anau
#Text=Manapouri
#Text=Doubtful Sound
#Text=See
#Text=Homer Tunnel
#Text=Hollyford Valley
#Text=Lake Te Anau
#Text=and Te Ana-au cave
#Text=Lake Manapouri
#Text=, especially the West Arm and Manapouri Power Station .
#Text=Take a bus trip over the Wilmot Pass to Deep Cove .

#Text=The power station , one of New Zealand 's largest , has been carved out of solid rock below the lake and two tailrace tunnels take the water that passes through the power station to Deep Cove , 10 km away .
#Text=The only evidence that there is a power station nearby is the power lines that disappear into the ground !
#Text=Do
#Text=Walk
#Text=.
#Text=Take a trip through the amazing wilderness on either a day trip or overnight .
#Text=The Department of Conservation maintains and , part of the year , staffs the park 's tracks .
#Text=The tracks get busy at certain times of the year and can require bookings for the huts , so it s a good option to inquire at an information center before setting off .
#Text=Hollyford Track
#Text=.
#Text=Guided walks are available .
#Text=Hump Ridge Track
#Text=.
#Text=Guided walks are available .
#Text=Kepler Track
#Text=.
#Text=Walk the Manapouri end of the track for a nice day hike , or dive all the way into the backcountry for an overnight .
#Text=Milford Track
#Text=.
#Text=One of the DOC 's " Great Walks " and considered by many to be one of the best walks in the world .
#Text=Guided walks are available .
#Text=A four-day , three-night 53.5-km track that starts at the head of Lake Te Anau and ends at Milford Sound .
#Text=Bookings essential .
#Text=Routeburn
#Text=.
#Text=Take the Routeburn for a overnight trip and cross into the neighboring Mount Aspiring National Park .
#Text=Guided walks are available .
#Text=The Dusky track .
#Text=A harder , longer tramp joins Lake Hauroko to Lake Manapouri .
#Text=Hunting
#Text=for the introduced species of red deer , wapiti and possums is permitted and a permit can be obtained from the Fiordland National Park Visitor Centre .
#Text=These introduced species are considered pests and there is an ongoing eradication programme to control these animal populations and eventually eliminate them .
#Text=The moose was introduced here but is thought to have died out .
#Text=Fishing
#Text=for brown and rainbow trout requires a licence and compliance with regulations .
